results.title: Classic tales; English Gentlemen
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “The Best of British”.
The ultimate collection of scenes from feature films inspired by the literary giants Shakespeare, Shaw, Dickens, Wilde and Wells. Some of the great classic films based on literature are featured including “Oliver Twist”, “Caesar and Cleopatra” and ‘The Importance of being Earnest’. In the episode entitled the “English gentlemen”, the image of this stereotype as portrayed in film is discussed. It is a reflection on the urbane and sometimes eccentric characters portrayed by such stars as Rex Harrison, Michael Wilding and Stanley Holloway. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

results.title: The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey
results.creator_credit: Various, Reverse Angle Productions and Vulcan (US)
results.brief_description: Seven documentary films individually directed with the director’s own viewpoint on the history of blues music. The series is presented by Martin Scorsese and is described in the trailer as “a musical journey to the roots of rock, soul and hip hop”. Directors include Mike Figgis, Clint Eastwood, Charles Burnett, Wim Wenders, Richard Pearce, Rober Kenner, and Marc Levin. — [319237] Red White and Blues (Figgis) — [319233] Piano Blues (Eastwood) — [319234] Warming by the Devil’s fire (Burnett) — [319235] The Soul of a man (Wenders) — [319236] The Road to Memphis (Pearce, Kenner) — [319238] Godfathers and sons (Levin) — [319239] Feel like going home (Scosese)

results.title: Feel like going home
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey [DVD]”.
Part of Martin Scorsese’s “The Blues Collection”, “Feel like going home” is Scorsese’s own directorial contribution, tracing the blues from the Mississippi Delta back to its roots in the Niger River, Mali. Musician Corey Harris acts as a guide along the journey, conducting interviews with a variety of musicians and engaging in song with several. Whilst examining the musical milieu of the Mississippi Delta, Scorsese addresses the work of Alan Lomax, the pioneering musicologist who recorded innumerable obscure American musicians and singers. Presents brilliant vintage footage of early blues men, such as Son House and John Lee Hooker whilst painting a picture of the rural poverty that dominated the lives of these future greats. Original performances include Willie King, Corey Harris, Taj Mahal, Keb Mo, Otha Turner, Habib Koite, Salif Keita, and Ali Farke Toure.

results.title: Fine and dandy; Things that go bump in the night
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Best of British”.
Fine and dandy illustrates the fame of British costume dramas in all their lavishness. A wonderfully romantic outcome was the main feature of these films which focused on the purity of love, whether the character was a lusty lord or a defenceless maiden. From malevolent spirits to demonic murderers, benevolent ghosts to spooky fortune tellers, British horror films will have you screaming and laughing in turn. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

results.title: The all singing all dancing show; Power and prejudice
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Best of British”.
The All singing all dancing show features a time when Britain produced screen musicals that were innovative, exciting and visually stunning. This episode uncovers jewels with scenes from films like “The Red shoes” and “London town”, and a host of stars including Jessie Matthews, Kay Kendall and Moira Shearer. “Power and Prejudice” focuses on films that reflect social attitudes, struggles and problems of ordinary people. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

results.title: Leave 'em laughing; The Eccentrics
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Best of British”.
Leave ‘em laughing features scenes from some of the finest British comedies and some of its greatest comedians; Sid Field, Jerry Desmond, Norman Wisdom, Will Hay and the Carry On Gang. “Eccentrics” is filled with some of the most endearing characters to appear on film; Dame Edith Evans, Sir Michael Redgrave, Cecil Parker, Alistair Sim, Peter Sellers and the gentle, amusing and complusive to watch, Margaret Rutherford. This volume captures the essence of British comedy at its best. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

results.title: The Breakthrough series
results.brief_description: An award winning series of eight films, aimed at adolescents, dealing with violence, stress, divorce, step-parents, death, racism, conflict and political action. The issues are presented in an entertaining and direct manner, hopefully leading to empowerment rather than a feeling of hopelessness.

results.title: Hit and Miss/One Voice
results.creator_credit: Pip Karmel, Stephen Ramsey, Pamela Williams and Ron Saunders
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Breakthrough series”.
In “Hit and Miss” we meet Adam, dealing with the pressures of school and family. The resulting conflict is resolved in a constructive way. A teenager who decides to take part in an anti-logging protest is featured in “One Voice” Amber is ostracised by her peers, but supported by her parents. Watch her confidence increase as she pursues her beliefs undeterred by the attitudes of her peers.

results.title: In Loving Memory. Alice
results.creator_credit: Michael Riley, Pamela Williams, Ron Saunders and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Breakthrough series”.
In Loving Memory - we meet Mary who develops cancer in primary school, and see the effects that the illness and treatment have on her life. Mary examines her relationship with family and friends and the value she puts on life. In “Alice” we meet an Aboriginal teenager who is subjected to racism, both at school and in the community. The effects of prejudice are seen as we eavesdrop on her thoughts and watch her achieve her ambitions despite the attacks on her self confidence.
